How to live with purpose using goals and tasks!

Do you like ever shuffling on in an endless grind of stuff to do, emails to answer and yet another new project? Neither do I. I want to live with purpose and values, rather than have an email inbox as a publicly-writable to do list, just because that is “just how it works”. And there’s a relatively simple way to bring more purpose into daily work: recurring checklists for review, plan and reflect.

If you’re anything like me, you use an application for tracking to do-lists. These are great for actionable tasks and getting things done. My favourite is Things. I also use a journal for, among other things, reflection on personal development and life goals. David Allen calls these the runway actions and 50,000ft horizon of focus, respectively. To live more deliberately, align these two.

Aligning horizons of focus

What are practical steps to feed our purpose, values and goals into our day-to-day to do-list? Assuming clarity of purpose and values, this is how I do it:

  1. Quarterly goals: every quarter, I review my purpose, value and life balance; from that I write one to three goals for the next three months.
  2. Weekly review: every week, on Monday morning I do a weekly review to capture open loops, clean up my to do lists and set weekly goals.
  3. Daily check-in: every morning I review my tasks for the day and set one to three daily goals.
  4. Daily check-out: every afternoon before I leave work, I review my progress and migrate any open tasks to the next day. As they say, tomorrow begins today.

Increasing the odds of success

None of these steps are particularly hard to do, but they consume creative energy. Between cute cat pictures on the internet and unread messages in your inbox, 1

In order to do what’s right instead of what is convenient, we need all the help we can get. Here’s how I use Things to support this process:

  • I have set up recurring tasks for all these events. This ensures they’re just another thing to do on any given day.
    1. Sub item 1
      • foo
    2. Sub item 2
  • These recurring tasks have reminders set for the start or end of the day, so I am reminded about them when I come into work or am about to leave.
  • The tasks contain checklists to make it remove as much friction as possible.
  • I use tags to track particularly simple, low-energy tasks and bigger, focus-required tasks.

The routine

On Monday morning I am to do a weekly review. I follow the check list to capture open loops, groom my to do-list and set weekly goals based on my quarterly goals and last week’s progress.

Every other morning of the week, I am reminded to plan my day by picking one to three major tasks to complete and some minor, low-energy stuff. Every afternoon before I leave the office, I am triggered to reflect on my progress and prepare for tomorrow.

Every quarter, I’m reminded to review last quarter’s results and come up with new goals for the upcoming quarter. My journal contains my purpose and values and a bunch of personal trackers, making it easy to think about the upcoming months in terms of what I want to do, rather than what the world has put on my plate.

Use tools and events to live purposefully

I use Things to set recurring tasks with reminders and checklists to support a process of regular reflection and planning with my journal based on daily, weekly and quarterly goals. I’ve been using this system for a while now and it has given me a real sense of agency and tranquility. Give it a try and see what works for you.
